element.name: Kilmashogue by daraconn, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

description.p: The cache container is a black decontamination container. It is hidden near a prehistoric wedge-tomb on the northern slopes of Kilmashogue Mountain, adjacent to the Wicklow Way and convenient to a car-park. Unfortunately the approach to the cache location is steep and is not suitable for wheelchairs or buggies. The cache is not in the precincts of the monument. You will not need to interfere with the monument to find the cache.

long-description.p: Car/Cycle Approaching along College Road from Dundrum/Sandyford, or Whitechurch Road from Rathfarnham, pass under the M50 at Kilmashogue Bridge. A left turn at the roundabout will take you up Kilmashogue Lane. After 1 km turn left and enter the car park.

Public Transport Unfortunately this location is not easily accessible by public transport. The most attractive option is to take Dublin Bus route 16 to the gate of Marlay Park, and follow the waymarked Wicklow Way through the park and up to the cache location. Alternatively, route 15C terminates in Whitechurch. Either way, you will have to walk around 2.5 km to the cache.

This gallery grave was built by Neolithic farmers around 4000 years ago. It went unrecorded until 1950, when the then landowner reported it to the Inspector of National Monuments. Its importance was immediately realised and the site was excavated.

Gallery graves were constructed by raising rows of upright stones and laying roof-slabs across the top to form a covered passage-way. Along the passage-way were burial chambers. In this example, the plan seems to consist of an antechamber, a large main chamber, and possibly a smaller chamber to the rear.

The whole structure was once topped with a cairn of rocks and soil, retained by a ring of kerb-stones. The cairn and roof-slabs have been plundered for building materials, leaving the uprights, gallery floor and kerb stones exposed, as well as a sill-stone at the entrance of the main chamber.

In cases such as this where the gallery is wider and taller at the entrance than at the rear, the structure is known as a "wedge tomb". This is one of 3 wedge tombs in the Barony of Rathdown, the other two being Ballyedmonduff on the east slope of Two Rock Mountain and Laughanstown adjacent to Junction 16 (Loughlinstown/Shankill) on the M50.
Characteristic features of a wedge tomb include "double-lined" or in this case "triple-lined" walls, where the side walls of the gallery consist of two or three rows of stones.

A later addition to the site was the insertion of Bronze Age burial "cists" (stone boxes) into the cairn. These are still visible, and during the excavation yielded funerary urns, bones and pottery. No artefacts or remains connected with the original Neolithic monument were found.
Kilbride-Jones, H.E. The excavation of an unrecorded Megalithic tomb on Kilmashogue Mountain, Co. Dublin Proceedings of the Royal Irish Academy Vol 56 (1953-54) 461-479
Kathleen Turner; “If You Seek Monuments - a guide to the antiquities of the Barony of Rathdown” (Rathmichael Historical Society, 1983)

element.additional-waypoints:
RE11N3X - Kilmashogue Forest Car Park Entrance
N 53° 15.502 W 006° 16.600
element.encoded-hints: At the base of a tree under a rock.

ul.li:
2010-06-12T19:00:00Z : Found it by BlueFoxPL
Another great day for caching... found with some friends. TFTC.

2010-06-12T19:00:00Z : Found it by Wicca Cailín
Beautiful spot thanks for bringing us here. Could almost hear the chanting in the trees. Found with Blue Fox PL. TFTC.

2010-06-10T19:00:00Z : Found it by colmyster
Absolutley stunning spot. Got here at around 7 so the sun was shining in through the canopy just on the stones which made the place incredibly eerie. You could almost feel the druid's presence... TFTC
In: Dinosaur Out: travel bug

2010-05-25T19:00:00Z : Found it by Serapis
Easy to dismiss the grave as ‘a pile of auld stones’. It was lovely to sit here today - very peaceful and it was nice to think about the people who built, lived near by and eventually interred here. A short walk away you can look over Dublin city and also think about the people who build, live and die there, after 2 seconds I got into the car and turned on Joe Duffy. A lady was graphically describing how her pet lab was found garrotted and brutally dismembered by some 'people'. What a world….[:(] TFTC. Serapis.

2010-04-11T19:00:00Z : Found it by AbbeyAckbar
(#623 @ 15:45) Wow! never been here before. The view is great. It was a short walk from the carpark to the cache site were the cache was quickly found.
TFTC

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Kilmashogue
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description:
Cache Description

The cache container is a black decontamination container. It is hidden near a prehistoric wedge-tomb on the northern slopes of Kilmashogue Mountain, adjacent to the Wicklow Way and convenient to a car-park. Unfortunately the approach to the cache location is steep and is not suitable for wheelchairs or buggies. The cache is not in the precincts of the monument. You will not need to interfere with the monument to find the cache.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Access

Car/Cycle Approaching along College Road from Dundrum/Sandyford, or Whitechurch Road from Rathfarnham, pass under the M50 at Kilmashogue Bridge. A left turn at the roundabout will take you up Kilmashogue Lane. After 1 km turn left and enter the car park.

Public Transport Unfortunately this location is not easily accessible by public transport. The most attractive option is to take Dublin Bus route 16 to the gate of Marlay Park, and follow the waymarked Wicklow Way through the park and up to the cache location. Alternatively, route 15C terminates in Whitechurch. Either way, you will have to walk around 2.5 km to the cache.

Description of the Monument

This gallery grave was built by Neolithic farmers around 4000 years ago. It went unrecorded until 1950, when the then landowner reported it to the Inspector of National Monuments. Its importance was immediately realised and the site was excavated.

Gallery graves were constructed by raising rows of upright stones and laying roof-slabs across the top to form a covered passage-way. Along the passage-way were burial chambers. In this example, the plan seems to consist of an antechamber, a large main chamber, and possibly a smaller chamber to the rear.

The whole structure was once topped with a cairn of rocks and soil, retained by a ring of kerb-stones. The cairn and roof-slabs have been plundered for building materials, leaving the uprights, gallery floor and kerb stones exposed, as well as a sill-stone at the entrance of the main chamber.

In cases such as this where the gallery is wider and taller at the entrance than at the rear, the structure is known as a "wedge tomb". This is one of 3 wedge tombs in the Barony of Rathdown, the other two being Ballyedmonduff on the east slope of Two Rock Mountain and Laughanstown adjacent to Junction 16 (Loughlinstown/Shankill) on the M50.

Characteristic features of a wedge tomb include "double-lined" or in this case "triple-lined" walls, where the side walls of the gallery consist of two or three rows of stones.

A later addition to the site was the insertion of Bronze Age burial "cists" (stone boxes) into the cairn. These are still visible, and during the excavation yielded funerary urns, bones and pottery. No artefacts or remains connected with the original Neolithic monument were found.

References

Kilbride-Jones, H.E. The excavation of an unrecorded Megalithic tomb on Kilmashogue Mountain, Co. Dublin Proceedings of the Royal Irish Academy Vol 56 (1953-54) 461-479

Kathleen Turner; “If You Seek Monuments - a guide to the antiquities of the Barony of Rathdown” (Rathmichael Historical Society, 1983)

Additional Waypoints

RE11N3X - Kilmashogue Forest Car Park Entrance
N 53° 15.502 W 006° 16.600
